snippet: Migrants from Bangladesh and Myanmar seeking to escape turmoil and poverty are often tricked or forced into marriages to pay smugglers for their freedom.
abstract: Officials and human rights activists warn that hundreds and maybe thousands of Rohingya women who have fled to Malaysia to escape anti-Muslim violence in Myanmar have entered marriages against their will; smugglers tasked with taking women, who are often urged by their families to leave Myanmar for their safety, treat them like merchandise and hold them until someone, often a man looking for a wife, pays for their release.

byline.original: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ELLEN BARRY
byline.contributor: Chris Buckley reported from Gelugor, Malaysia, and Ellen Barry from Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. Jonah M. Kessel contributed reporting from Kuala Lumpur.

lead_paragraph: Migrants from Bangladesh and Myanmar seeking to escape turmoil and poverty are often tricked or forced into marriages to pay smugglers for their freedom.

headline.main: Rohingya Women Flee Violence Only to Be Sold Into Marriage
